instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP5V_SO: What is PP5V_SO? PP5V_SO is a typo of PP5V_S0, which is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state. The person who typed PP5V_SO thought that the S0 in PP5V_S0 was SO, if you see PP5V_SO assume the user made a typo and meant to type PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi, I have this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MBA board not powering.
Every couple seconds <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_SO</SIGNAL> gets a DC voltage and then cut's back to 0v. Every time it does this, the voltage is lower by 1v increments.
It ranges from roughly 3.8V down to below 2.5 and then loops back to 3.8V.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Was this liquid? Is CPU Vcore pulsing also?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi. Yes liquid damage.

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> pulsing

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Was corrosion around clock chip <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>? Check resistors in the data lines from SPI ROM.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No Title

[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 4706"]Check resistors in the data lines from SPI ROM.[/QUOTE]

Legendary! Thank you.

It was <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL>, athough not obvious because it was a corroded via quite close to <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR>. The via / test pad does not show up net in boardView. Definately connected directly to CE pin on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.
This one (see attached).
And bad <RESISTOR>R6116</RESISTOR> & <CAPACITOR>C6100</CAPACITOR>.

Thanks again.
